At first I gave this company a 1-star review. It appeared that my watch had come already linked to someone else's account and if that's the case, there's no way to unlink it without that person's password. Along about 3am I sat bolt upright in bed with a realization. What if it was in demo mode? Five minutes later, my watch was set up to my account and was rocking along beautifully. Thus far, everything I've tried has worked beautifully, including the ECG (EKG) and the cellular function.
So why the 4-star review for a watch that I'm rapidly coming to love? It's because of the company. Sending the watch in demo mode with no documentation whatsoever was unprofessional. If they are going to sell refurbished watches, the watch should have a factory reset performed and be ready to link to the new user's account on arrival. This cost me quite a bit of distress until it dawned on me after hours of fighting with it that the watch might have been in demo mode. And at that, I had to research until I found the YouTube video. Was it worth it? I think so, but if you're wanting a watch that will come to you in the same state that it would have from Apple, this probably isn't the place to shop.

Data:
This is more of an FYI rather than a review. Apple incorrectly lists ALL series 4 models as having sapphire glass. THIS IS NOT TRUE. The aluminum case models come with Ion-X glass which is NOT as scratch resistant as sapphire. I purchased a 4 series with an aluminum case and confirmed with a Diamond Selector (used to test diamonds, but is commonly used to test watch glass) that it does not have sapphire. See the attached video. I compared the Apple watch to two other Citizen watches. The one on the left has a mineral crystal, the one in the middle has a sapphire crystal. Red means sapphire, NO red means something else (Mineral, Gorilla, Ion-X etc.).
Now, Ion-X glass is not necessarily a bad thing. Sapphire glass is FAR more scratch resistant than Ion-X. However, Ion-X is FAR more shatter resistant. If you are going to be hard on your watch like working manual labor, constantly hitting it against hard objects, prone to dropping, then you should go with the Ion-X glass. Yes it is going to scratch on you, but it is much less likely to completely break/shatter. If you are simply wearing it for everyday activities with no regular threat of smashing or dropping it, then you should go with sapphire. There is still the possibility of it shattering when dropped or hit on a hard surface, but it will remain virtually scratch-free.
